captions.text: - I possess many important qualities,

such as the ability to
complete this application
three hours before the deadline. (laughs)
(light music)

- It is completely obvious
that I am totally burnt out.

- My mom is standing over
my shoulder right now,

so this has no trace
of my real personality.
- I'm using words I literally learned
a minute ago on Thesaurus.com.
- I got this opinion off CNN.com.
- I'm trying to hide the fact
that I'm a privileged white person.
- I consider Abraham Lincoln to be my hero
because you've heard of him,
and this is not a controversial opinion.
- I will write anything you want to hear,

just so I can get out
of this terrible town.
- Here's where I pretend like your school
is my first and only choice.
- You're my safety school, but I'm not
going to say that.

- I'm only applying to
college because my parents
will kill me if I don't.

- I'm making myself sound
like a serious student,
but I'm probably just going to drink
malt liquor for four years.
- I'm mentioning how excited I am

about your small class
size and personalized
attention because you mentioned it
five times on your website.
- Now I will tell you about the one time
I visited another country to put
a cultured spin on myself.
- I did a lot of community service,
and by community service, I mean
I donated blood once.
For cookies!
- I live in a rich Jewish neighborhood.
Does that count as diversity?
- I'm only name-dropping my grandfather
because he's an alumni.
- If this wasn't a college essay,
this would be considered way oversharing.

- [Voiceover] I know
what it means to suffer.

I went through a horrible
breakup sophomore year.
He's now dating my best friend,
so I understand the world.

title: If People Were Honest In College Application Essays

comments.text: That privileges white person shit pissed me off.﻿

Is writing an essay as part of a college application an American thing?

comments.author: Matthew Welke

comments.text:
This is so weird. I applied to 3 different universities in Canada and 
didn't have to write an essay. All they wanted was my grades, and there was 
even a nice provincial-wide system that I could put those into to apply to 
any school in the province.
The US is so weird. Plus, I find it weird that university=college down 
there. They are not the same thing here.﻿
comments.author: gocanadayayyy

comments.text:
Ok, I was referring to how people in university in the states are always 
talking about the fact that they're studying "at college" or living "that 
college life" like the words seem to be interchangeable to me, whereas you 
don't get that up here at all.
comments.author: gocanadayayyy

comments.text:
uh... They aren't. University is not college here in the US. You go to 
college (total of 2 years) for an associate degree and then transfer to 
university (4 years) of your choice for a bachelor degree. Most people who 
go to college are those who want to release the financial burden of 
university or they aren't accepted to university right after high school 
graduation. College is a different path. It is not the same as university.

I feel SO lucky that I get to go to university in Australia. It sounds

and go to uni.

The payments can be a lot easier as well. There's a way that you can just 
get meager amounts taken out of your pay when you get a job, and if you 
don't get a job you never even have to pay for the course. I'm pretty sure 
that's true but not 100%.﻿

comments.text:
It annoys me when people who do this kind of shit apply to colleges.  They 
don't even take it fucking seriously.  Meanwhile, all the international 
students out there work their ass off to get into the 10-20% of spots 
available to them, and in order to do that, must get above 2200s in SATs 
and get between 70% and 100% on finals to even be CONSIDERED (of course, 
depending on the college).  In terms of a capitalist approach, keeping it 
more open to international students will earn them up to 3x more money. 
 Increase the GDP!  More employment!  Higher wages!﻿

comments.text:
I remember mine required two essays one had to be about why you wanted the 
major you were applying for and the other had to be about a recent life 
changing moment in your life. Naturally the story I picked for the second 
one was the time I saved my dad's life when he had renal failure. Can't get 
much more life changing than dealing with a parent's life hanging by a 
thread. I had a good academic background but I've wondered how much of a 
role that second essay played into me getting into UC Davis. If it played a 
large role well then I guess thank you dad for nearly dying.﻿
comments.author: ArashiTsurugi

comments.text:

comments.author: Kugel

comments.text:
I never even knew it was such a common thing to lie during application 
letters.
I wrote my essay honestly, and I also truthfully said the other colleges I 
planned on applying to, etc.
I've been accepted into my top colleges so far, so don't think you have to 
lie. The admission directors will probably appreciate truthful applications 
more than they appreciate over thought, and obvious made up statements.﻿

comments.text:
God..universities in United States are terrible.. I am an international 
student, however I attended all 4 years of high school with 95 GPA and 33 
on my ACT. Because I am international I CAN'T get loans or financial aid; 
only private loans with crazyyy interests. Universities tend to ignore the 
fact that I have to pay all of my tuition and offer little or no merit 
scholarship to international students.﻿

comments.author: Gwen H

comments.text:
I agree. I don't understand why we have to put our race on the application 
for schools and jobs. Sometimes they give you the option to put your race 
and gender. Sometimes, I think if I don't put it, would they even consider 
my application regardless of my qualifications. I have no problem with 
employers hiring individuals for their effort/qualifications. That's best. 
But Affirmative Action primarily was implemented because minorities weren't 
given a chance regardless if they fit the qualifications. I would like to 
see it done away with myself. Then we'll see if employers care about race.

comments.text:
It depends on what school you go to. Some schools might have a lot of 
African American students, so if you apply there you'll have a lower chance 
of getting in. But if a school has a lot of other races and barely any 
African Americans it will accept as many as they can (only if they are 
actually good students). It's basically whatever the college is looking for 
at the time helps or doesn't help your chance of getting in.
